No mention of the Peppered Moth? During the Industrial Revolution in the UK (~1760- 1830) it was noted that popuations of this species of moth, usually peppered black and white (hence the name), were displaying darker colourations in some areas than others. Eventually it was realised that in areas near big cities, which at the time usually relied on burning large amounts of coal to power their machinery, were being covered in dark residue from the burning coal which made the moths stand out and be easier to see when they rested during the day, ruining their natural camouflage and exposing them to predation. To combat this, the populations of moths in the urbanised areas tended to be darker than their rural counterparts.It was also noted that once most of those factories stopped relying on coal (as alternative energy sources were discovered), the air quality cleared up and the (newer, younger) trees in the area maintained their natural colouration, but by then the darker coloured moths were more prevelant and once again their camouflage betrayed them until the species responded yet again to by lightening to adjust to the conditions they found themselves in.

None of these examples prove evolutionary theory, i.e. macroevolution, the changing of one lifeform (body plan) into another. They are either examples of microevolution, in which some genes within a species become more common within the species due to external factors (but it's still the same species!) or extinction. They generally involve a reduction in genetic diversity, whereas macroevolution requires a spontaneous increase in beneficial genetic diversity, which is practically impossible.

All of this is conflating adaptation and survival heuristics with evolution, those are very distinct things. If a bacteria could always eat plastic, it won't happen until it has plastic. If only one food source is available or there is a change in availability there will be changes in the population demographics based on preference and availability. The key distinction is that there is variation in a species population and that is getting glossed over. There were already birds with shorter wings that isn't a new trait, it is just the trait that survived or out bred. Birds changing their wing lengths provides no mechanism for them to say turn into mammals.

Another issue is classification and hybridization, which could be an alternative explanation for why misquotes isolated in subways couldn't breed when reintroduced. It could be the result of generational inbreeding or changes in hybrid populations (Tiger + Lion = Liger which is fertile, but Donkey+ Horse = Mule (which has an odd number of chromosomes). It is nearly impossible to capture, detect, and monitor specific hybrids for misquotes or study their trinary effects where as one hybrid might be fertile it might not be with another hybrid, this is genetic selection, and will always produce Misquotes and not eventual coach potatoes watching TV as suggested in the video.

I have observed rapid evolution over the course of some 40 years.   Two examples.  A species of clam that lives near me in Florida in the mud used to be randomly bright pink, light pink or white.  A parent could have all three in the hundreds every time they reproduce.   So if you were out collecting their shells you would be likely to see all three colors in equal amounts.  Shell crafters, people who make decorative objects from seashells often pick brightly colored shells to harvest as opposed to planer looking shells.  Shell crafting has been going on since the sailor's valentine craze of the Victorian era but it has grown to a wider scale here in Florida so much so that some county's ban harvesting live shells altogether.   So due to the popularity of brightly colored shells, the crafters would harvest only the pink ones leaving the white ones to survive to reproduce.   In 1979, as I said, the color demographics were more or less even.  Today, you will easily find the white ones but hardly ever will you find either of the pink shades.   A similar thing happened with it's distant cousin, another clam but that one comes in a huge variety of colors ranging from all white to every color of the rainbow and often many colors at once.  At least that was the case again 40 years ago but today, the demographics of that clam is roughly 80% white and 20% multi colored.  And like the other species, any parent can reproduce any of the colors and in fact will have a thousand offspring at a time and every color of the rainbow will be represented in one mass of eggs but mostly today you see white ones.   I predict that 2nd species of clam will be 96% White in 40 years and 99% white in 120 years and in a few more centuries, all color will be bred out of both species.   There is also a species of sea snail that when first discovered was up to 18" long and quite heavy.  The snail would simply keep reproducing throughout it's life and just get bigger and bigger.  Due to harvesting preferences being for the largest display worthy specimens, you never see this species over a foot long any more.  But also this species tended to reproduce only after it reached 10 inches in length.  A malacologist once told me that they simply didn't reach sexual maturity until they were 10 inches long.  Prior to that any offspring would be deformed or sickly.   Recently I have observed specimens as small as six inches laying eggs and when I examined some under a microscope I found they were perfectly formed.  I saw one in a museum once that was 22 1/2 inches long.  It was accompanied by an egg case that was 2 1/2 inches thick.  The egg cases I see today are half an inch thick.  It's basically the same species but now I think we could call today's version a sub species, a sort of pigmy version of their ancestors.   To my knowledge no specimen of that species over 14 inches long has been seen alive since the 1970's.  All this said,  they are actually a very common species.  I could go out into the harbor near my house at low tide and there is a 75% chance I could fill a shopping bag with them in an hour.  Smaller specimens have little commercial value but the foot long or nearly foot long specimens sell for about $50 in souvenir shops.

I'm not sure if that explanation about swallows is entirely correct. Within a species, there is always a difference in characteristics (beak length, wingspan etc). In some habitats, they don't necessarily matter, but they might in others. e.g.: near roads/bridges, the habitat might naturally select for longer wingspans to die easily, which means the shorter wing birds get to reproduce more, and this makes shorter wingspans more pronounced in a short time.

The same shorter wingspan could well be detrimental or neutral in a different habitat. That's how natural selection works. It's quite possible that multiple populations of swallows could be separated geographically or in different habitats, and therefore could favour different characteristics. Sometimes, birds within the same population could evolve to benefit from different diet niches (as Darwin's finches did).

I'm very happy to see this video. The problem that troubled Darwin greatly was there seemed to be so few fossils of 'intermediate' species, those that showed gradual speciation. Darwin believed that evolution was slow and proceeded by gradual steps. Nowadays we know that just a few changes in genes are enough to bring about rather dramatic and abrupt change in the species, so that in just a few generations the old population would have been replaced by the new due to selection pressure. If conditions then remain static for a long time, these populations would remain static until again confronted with quickly changing selection pressure, whereupon the speciation change would take place within a short time. Hence the paucity of 'intermediate' species. Well done, keep it up!

BUTTERFLIES Falsify Evolution:
1- The butterfly has two distinctly different body plans
2- Only the second one has the means of fertilisation and reproduction
3- Evolution assumes it evolved from a creature with one body plan and its own means of fertilisation and reproduction
4- The second body plan cannot function until it is complete in both a male and a female simultaneously
5- Evolution must develop complimentary second body plans in male and female by random mutations without the aid of natural selection over generations
6- Evolution cannot by definition develop a whole body plan without the benefit of natural selection contradicting the basis of the theory
7- It is fanciful to imagine the random process could time the moment of transfer of the complex reproductive mechanism from the first to the second body plan in both a male and female to coincide exactly at the moment when those body plans were complete!
8- "We can often learn about evolution from the fossil record, but there are relatively few butterfly fossils. Those that do exist, like the 40-million-year-old Prodryas persophone, are remarkably similar to modern-day forms—so the fossil record sheds little light on the origin of today's butterflies." The Peppered Moth is not an example of evolution!

At one point in time, it seemed as though more dark-colored moths were eaten by birds, but, for whatever reason, in time more light-colored varieties were consumed by the lurking winged predators. What happened within the moth population was just a swing in the number of colored moths, more one season and fewer the next. There was absolutely no change in the moths themselves, for both light and dark moths existed before the study, and identical light and dark moths existed after the study. The question we need to ask ourselves is this: How long would it take for this process to change a single feature of the peppered moth, or change it into something else? All you have described is just the survival of those individuals within an existing population, which has an advantageous trait. They then passed on those genetic traits to their offspring. So the latter generations had a high proportion of individuals with the advantageous trait. They then got to pass on their genes. It's just selection of an existing trait within a population. Take peppered moths for instance - the natural, pre-industrial Revolution population of moths had a fairly high proportion of light coloured to dark coloured individuals within the population. They would rest on the bark of light coloured trees. The dark moths stood out more than their light coloured brethren and were more easily seen by predatory birds, and were eaten. Dead moths don't reproduce. When the industrial Revolution occurred, a lot of soot was produced, which darkened the trees on which the moths rested. So now, the light coloured moths stood out against the background and were more heavily predated upon, with the dark coloured moths surviving to pass on their dark coloured genes. Thus you had a population shift from light coloured to dark coloured moths being the dominant form. No new information was required - just the selection of an advantageous existing trait. The same happens with fish, elephants and bacteria. If that population pressure continues - soon, only those with the advantageous trait survive in the local breeding population, and lose altogether the previous diversity of genetic variability available for passing on. That is speciation, or sub-speciation or varietisation - call it what you will.

Natural selection is not evolution - many confuse this point. Those creatures with features that happen to have an advantage in a changing environment are the ones that get to breed, because the others died off. Evolution per se is a myth. Natural selection however, with its variations within a species is just that. No need to imagine cats evolving into a dogs, that will never happen. The fossil record shows each kind of life form was highly developed from the beginning. Transitional forms from one species to other has been shown to be impossible. Those insects for e.g. that survive the latest pesticide, have had that ability to do just that forever. All the rest of their kind died off & they survived to breed & replace the non-resistant ones. No evolution occurred here, merely natural selection, & that's all it's ever been.

playing fast and loose with the terminology spewed out by evolutionary biologists is a dangerous game. 'Evolutionary rescue' just means 'adaptation'. The cliff swallow is able to behaviourally adapt to traffic and they thrive, the slower ones are culled by what I call 'natural deselection'. Adaptive behaviours and wings are both within the genetic capability of the cliff swallow. This ADAPTATION is the same as the so-called 'evolution' of the peppered moth, Biston betularia, in response to sooty polution in its environment. All it did was increase the proportion of fully black-winged moths, but the coloration of the moth population ALWAYS included a range of all black, peppered, and all-white moths. Only the frequency of the all blacks changed. And when the pollution went away, the proportion of all blacks dropped to normal. Same with the swallows, (and the beaks of Darwin's finches), it is just adaptation, not speciation. Remember the title of Darwin's allegedly great book: 'On the Origin of Species' - but he did not provide the origin of ANY one species, let alone all of them on planet Earth. Evolution is mostly hooey.

I dispute every example.

2:47 Cliff swallows: This is not evolution; it is natural selection, which works against evolution by decreasing genetic diversity. In this case, the swallows already had the genetic diversity for long and short wings. Evolution requires an increase in genetic diversity. An example of evolution, if it were real, would be if swallows only had genes for long wings, then developed a brand new gene by random mutation for short wings. Also the rationale for the success of the short-winged birds is wrong: long wings make for better maneuverability than short wings.

3:05 Sport fish: This is microevolution: change within a species. It is not macroevolution, which is the claim of evolutionists that species change their body forms, but which has no basis in reality. Even after shrinking or reducing their lifespan, the fish here all remain the same species. The same thing happened to horses introduce to Iceland: within one generation their descendants were significantly smaller, due to environmental pressure (much-reduced food supply). Were their descendants a different species? No. Also, the logic is false: they didn't evolve to be smaller on average because fishermen favoured larger fish; they were smaller on average because the larger fish were fished out.

4:29 Mosquitoes: A change of diet doesn't make the underground mosquitoes a different species. People move to new areas and change their diet. Lack of hibernation doesn't make for a new species; it's a behavioural adaptation to the climate-controlled environment. Not needing blood to lay eggs harkens back to creation when all animals fed on plants. The fact that they can't mate with other mosquitoes also doesn't necessarily make them a new species, because there is no solid definition of a species. Would an archaeologist consider them different species if he found one of each in amber? Tough call. They are still mosquitoes. They haven't changed body form, e.g. into wasps. No evolution here.

6:09 Sea snakes: This is adaptation within a species, not evolution (a change from one species to another). So they had the genetic variability to become black. Not a big deal; humanity as a whole has the genes for a little melanin or a lot. People with a lot of melanin could cope with equatorial conditions; people with little melanin moved to temperate zones.

7:40 Ocean microbes: Full of BS. How do scientists know how much plastic is supposed to be in the ocean? Are they there to supervise each ship dumping garbage into the water? And if the patches aren't getting bigger, why are we screaming about turtles and banning plastic straws in Canada? Sounds like all is under control. And a change of diet does not make for a different species. Some Ideonella sakaiensis had a greater tolerance for plastic than others, and they flourished because of great supply. Most humans are lactose intolerant, but some can consume dairy, so they do. Same thing.

9:26 Butterflies: Where is the evolution here? The butterflies found a better food source, it disappeared, and they went extinct. Imagine North Americans losing their current food supply: would they go "back" to eating native vegetation, or would they starve? Exactly. Current generations don't even know what native vegetation is edible.

10:35 Elephants: No evolution here. Tuskless elephants are more common because of natural selection (or unnatural selection, in the case of human poaching, depending how you look at it). Tusklessness was in the elephants' genome, and tuskless elephants became the norm because the ones that developed tusks got shot. Fine. They're still elephants, just with reduced genetic complexity as the genetics for tusks gets weeded out. A given breed of dog is a basic, "original" dog (probably a wolf-like ancestor), with some of the genetics weeded out. Same thing; still a dog.

This is such a weak explanation of what is happening. Despite it being around for decades, Darwin's theory of evolution through natural selection is still poorly understood. Every thing shown here is just natural (environmental, even though it maybe man-made therefore "un-natural") selection on existing phenotypes in a population, the effect of which may seem remarkable and indeed is, but that just what Darwin explained. Genetic drift (accumulation of random mutations in a direction beneficial to the species) may indeed take thousands or millions of years, but a large enough population with existing variation can appear to change very suddenly, when all that is happening is selection.

In the suburbs of my hometown, Pittsburgh, everyone has a lawn. They keep it trimmed and relatively 'weed'-free. (Side note, I hate the truly monoculture lawns and miss the ones that have wild violets.) One of the side-products of the constant mowing is that the dandelions in the area are shorter than they used to be. I'm closing in on 40 and remember these LOOONG dandelion stems that you could wrap in a circle and- if skilled- tie into bracelets with the flower as the centerpiece.

Now, however, the ones that have survived and passed on their genetics are primarily short ones whose flowers don't crest over the standard height of a lawn. I've noticed it and pointed it out to neighbors and family and usually get a disinterested, "oh yeah- huh" reaction.

The large area where I grew up was primarily farmland until somewhere around the 70s when the housing plans and developments started, so it makes sense that up until that point, dandelions would've been tall to be able to compete in the scrubby farmlands and fields. They- and this video- make me wonder about what other changes have been taking place in the same timeframe that I haven't noticed.

I'd love to find out that Pittsburgh has something akin to the changing colors of the peppered moths of England since the 'burgh stopped being a steel town (and consequently constantly covered in soot.) Incidentally, the peppered moths probably could've been included in this video.I

The elephant example is actually a little scary since, as described, it means that population went through a very restrictive bottleneck which could have reduced genetic diversity. To the extent that the no-tusk trait is not random, the population could have lost alleles for other unrelated traits that by chance did not make it past the bottleneck. So in addition to not having tusks to forage, they may be less resilient to the next stressor that comes long. Now we come full circle to the caterpillar example.

HANK, I have an excellent candidate for a follow up to this: the Hawaiian rock wallaby. This species evolved from a single, sibling pair of Aussie rock wallabies, who escaped captivity in the 1940s, due to a tropical storm. Since their original habitat was so severe, and their dietary needs so extreme, it was at first assumed they'd have died off quickly. Nope. This sibling pair had lots of babies, who mated with each other, etc., until they were discovered in the 1990s, with differences in size, colour, diet, and most importantly, genital arrangement and chromosome structure, making them unable to mate with the species they came from. Unlike feral pigs, which destroyed many natural habitats, these wallabies ended up fitting in, and even help disperse seeds of various of their new food sources via their feces.

The adaptation this video describes has a name, EPIGENETICS, an inbuilt system in all living organisms that governs gene expression. It is today known that even the changes in the beak size and form of the famous Galapagos Finches are not evolutionary changes in the traditional sense, but due to rapid epigenetic adaptation. These adaptive changes are also reversible.

This is a fail. Selective adaption within a species is NOT evolution. In the case of the mosquitos adapting so much they could no-longer breed with unadapted ones, this is an outdated definition of species. It has been found some species, widespread over a continental scale can all breed with the adjacent group but not with groups at opposite ends of the species range. This is fairly well known in Grey Kangaroos for example & they are still regarded as one species. The mosquito example sounds extreme but the concept of species can not be defined by the ability to breed anymore as there are so many cases where that definition breaks down. The human construct of species has become rather arbitrary IMO. You need to go at least to the order level before you definitively have evolution. You can't even use chromosome count, otherwise down syndrome people would be considered not human and that is clearly not an acceptable view. Below order, variations are pretty much just promoting or rejecting existing genetic variation through selectivity (natural selection or selective breeding). While selectivity is hypothesised as a possible mechanism. It is not confirmed by actual observed, only hypothesized from the fossil record. Therefore it is not a fact no matter how convinced one may be. That's how science works, recorded observations are facts, conclusions are not. The best we can say is that based on the evidence, we think the most likely explanation is.......... The reason I am doing this rant is that IMO a lot of people over step the mark on what is conclusively known and I think science should be done scientifically & not by popular opinion.

Oh by the way, longer wings (with the same body weight and wing chord) are not faster, they are slower because L = 1/2 . p . V^2 . S . Cl so V = (2 . L /( p . S . Cl ))^(1/2). Therefore, reducing wing area "S" yields a higher velocity (airspeed). Shorter wings leads to higher induced drag winch simply changes the L/D ratio which is a measure of efficiency. This effects gliding range and rate of descent, not air speed. Air speed is determined by the ability to generate enough lift to counteract weight & thereby maintain level flight.

Some birds particularly ocean birds that rely on dynamic soaring in high winds and are not behaviourally tied to a limited geographic range, have high body weights and very narrow long (low area) wings. As weight/area is high, they achieve very high air speeds. Their narrow long wings give low induced drag, high lift/drag ratios performance that gives them an efficient shallow, long range gliding performance. But, this is not the case in the example given in the video. I suspect this example has been inappropriately transferred to the case in the video.

The point is that while holding other parameters fixed, reducing wing area, either by reducing wing chord or by reducing length, results in increased wing loading which increases airspeed for flight.

Another interesting rapid evolution example is the Australian cane toad. It was introduced as a natural predator for the cane beetle and has become one of the most destructive pest species in the country as has spread all the way from the East coast to Darwin in the North/West. This is a REALLY long way and involves travelling through a number of diverse environments. This has led to physical changed in the species. The cane toad populations that are found further West display features that would be beneficial in travelling the large distances required to reach a new habitat before it becomes saturated with members of their own species. They are significantly larger than the parent species and also have comparatively longer legs. Basically, this invading species has adapted traits that serve well for the vanguard simply reaching a new destination first and dominating the region before the smaller and shorter legged competitors arrive.

Additionally, native species that live in areas which have become inhabited by cane toads have also evolved to accommodate their presence. The Australian Red-Bellied Black Snake has evolved a smaller head because those with large enough jaws to ingest a poisonous adult toad died very quickly after doing so. Also, several species of Australian bird have developed a preference for flipping toads onto their backs and eating the non-poisonous parts of the toad. While this was initially believe to be a learned behavior, birds that are raised in captivity and never see other birds doing this do now seem to instinctively go for the underside of toads when encountering them for the first time.

Another rather famous example of this is the Peppered Moth also referred to as Darwin's moth.  A Peppered Moth is typically white with small black and gray spots which help them camouflage against the pale bark of the trees they live on.  Although there was a melanistic version, it was rather rare because it was more easily spotted by predators thus not surviving to pass on it's genes.  During the industrial revolution the tree bark in cities was stained black from pollution.  This caused the melanistic form of the moth to thrive in cities while the white form declined.  That trend continued until the mid 20th century when clean air laws put an end to the pollution and within a few generations the melanistic moths began to decline and the white colored Pepper Moth returned.

where I live, a decade ago it was extremely common in the spring for sparrows to make nests on roof tiles. Now I haven't seen a nest like this in 3 years or so.
What happens is, I live in a poor area and most houses have cheap roof tiles that don't insulate heat at all, but help during harsh winters and are hail-resistant enough. Its undulated shape makes easy nesting places for sparrows and they used to build nests there in the spring, but when summer arrived the tiles would get extremely hot and would cook the chicks until they jumped off too early and got eaten by dogs. That probably gave the sparrows that avoided roofs for nesting an advantage and now all of them make their nests in places like trees.

Also, in a town 4 hours away from here the sparrows have way more contrasting patterns while the ones here have more grayish, muted colors. That town is way less urbanized than here, so my guess is: more humans = more cats = more predation = more need for camouflage rather than attracting mates

Theres a lot of other physical and behavioral changes on birds here as the years pass, but I haven't quite figured out all of them yet.

The video occasionally hints or mentions that the hyper-evolution is caused by a relatively sudden and pronounced change in the selective pressures.  It's important to make clear that evolution is not some intelligent proactive response to the pressures. It occurs when a dramatic change in selective pressures changes which members are successful in passing on their genetic material to new generations.  If a significant number of long-winged sparrows die before they can breed, succeeding generations have less and less of the long-winged sparrow genes in the population.  If the selective pressure change is dramatic, the change can occur over relatively few generations.

Here is what drove a boy sitting in class listening to the drone of the 'science' teacher tell him it takes MILLIONS and MILLIONS of years for a slight change to happen to a species from the only thing that could do it: MUTATIONS.

Then I would hear in history class that 40,000 years ago we were all small, brown and living in the tropics. Then I would hear the other extreme: "In seven days God popped out the earth", easy peasy. I knew there were factors that had affected life/were affecting life that did not fit into the two 'options' I was given by 'adults'. I came up with a term to explain what I saw: 'genetic versatility'.

Now, jump forward 50 years and science is redefining their version of life development: Evolution. The word "evo-lution", came from a Latin term meaning 'unrolling', but was morphed into 'slow change' because of Darwinian theory of life development. What this video is talking about is "revolution" indication a sudden, radical change. It is now termed "genetic plasticity". What is in the genes and what is used by the life forms is not the same. Life has had to make fast adjustments all through existence of life on earth, that 'unrolling' of change to organisms can come from different sources and change much quicker than science has recognized in the past. There is no one answer, life has more 'up its sleeve' we have not discovered yet. Science can adjust, but it takes time, like, well, evolution . . . . . . . .

All of the changes described are controlled by epigenetics. Epigenetic changes are not evolution because the theory of evolution requires, by necessity of the definition of evolution, changes to the base code of DNA itself, which epigenetics does not do. Epigenetics does not cause new real species. It only causes "sub-species", which is a cheat name meaning that they are, in fact, the same species in every way.

A lack of mating only means they perceive each other as strangers the same way as human races perceive each other as different, but to the point that attraction is unlikely, but not impossible. Other epigenetic issues can cause creatures to be incompatible, but only because the opposing epigenitics or other causes, such as immune differences as between competing antogens (conflicting blood types) causes interference with survival of the fetus or later stages of development, but still has not changed the DNA. If it cannot change the DNA to the point of creating an actual new species with little relation to the originating species over many successive generations, then it cannot be true evolution, but is just breeding for favorable traits.

Thousands of breeds of dogs around the world have been bred by humans for thousands of years from just 3 originating dog breeds, but they all remain to be dogs. No one has even come close to breeding a new species out of dogs. If they force bred them every generation for 10,000 years, they would still be dogs. They could breed legless dogs, noseless dogs, flying dogs, snake dogs or giant flying snake terriers, but they would still be dogs with the same DNA. Only their epigentics would be wildly different. Take away the epigenetics of all breeds of lupines and you will be left with only one type.

You forgot another very distinct evolutionary pathway for mosquitoes. Urban mosquitoes are very different from their “wild” counterpart (people who went into forests know what I’m talking about). Through selective breeding, we created a new species of mosquitoes. They are smaller, more agile and more careful. They come out only when it gets darker. once the light goes off, they try to remain still, preferably on a darker surface. Also, they come out to fly maximum 1-2 individuals at a time; Even though, there could be 10 more hiding in the shadows.

I remember reading in my biology text in High School, back in the 70s, about a species of of moth in England that was various shades of gray; specimens collected at the beginning of the 1800s, when compared to specimens collected at the beginning of the 1900s, showed a noticeable difference - the earlier ones had a noticeably greater amount of lighter gray as compared to the latter ones, which were noticeably darker.  The naturalists noticed that the moths, which spent significant time perching on tree-trunks, were harder to see on the trunks, as the tree-trunks were, in many areas, darker due to soot from large numbers of nearby furnaces.  This made it harder for birds that preyed on them, to spot them.  So the species had originally been a lighter gray, as that made it harder to spotted by the predacious birds, but selective pressure had previously mitigated against the darker ones, as standing out on the lighter (earlier) tree-barks.

I'm surprised the peppered moth wasn't on this list. It's probably the most famous example, and the first one ever documented (and seen as a vindication of Darwin's then-controversial theory of natural selection). As a result it makes its way into many textbooks.

Basically, peppered moths in Britain turned from mostly white to nearly all black, particularly ones living in or near urban centres. This was because the industrial revolution covered the landscape in soot, and the black moths were better-camouflaged from predators.

Reminds me of a story from my biology teacher. She lived in Jamaica, and her landlord had gotten fifty gallons of SUPER cheap, hot pink paint in the early 80s. (Probably newly illegal lead containing paint from the U.S.) Because of this, her house was entirely hot pink. She had a large iguana on her roof, and many smaller lizards that lived inside and around the house that occasionally made an appearance. Finally, after living with the horrible paint scheme for many years, she convinced the landlord to let her paint the house other colors. When she did, she noticed a lot more small lizards — since they were all hot pink! The lizards had evolved to be pink to blend in better with the pink walls, so they wouldn’t be eaten by the iguana. But once the paint changed, they were very easy to see and she had a lot less lizards, and the ones that still were there gradually became less pink. Shows how fast natural selection can work.

Don't worry, I understand the occasional need for simplification, but for anyone that wants clarification:


No species actively attempts to avoid extinction. What happens is only those capable of surviving a challenge survive to pass the genes that assisted this on to the next generation. Then the next generation exhibits these characteristics, and on and on through generations until that characteristic is exhibited in most animals of the species. This process is evolution.


'Adaptation' is what one animal, or a population of animals, does during its lifetime. Adaptations cannot be genetically passed on. They can be taught and learnt thorugh generations, but the only time adaptations can be genetically passed on (ie be inherently expressed in an organism without exposure to other members of its species) is if they are exhibited in germ cells (sperm or eggs).


Basically, evolution is nature, adaptation is nurture.

1. Adaptation: How many bulldogs will it take to get a fennec fox? Never, because the parents of the dogs, gave the fennec fox its variational features and the same parents gave the bulldog its variational features. You can never get a fennec fox variation out of the bulldog variation. Evolution through adaptation does not exist.
2. Classification by similarities: Similarities don’t prove their related. All animals have good designs which work. Most cars have 4 wheels. It’s a good design, so it works. That does not prove that cars are related. To classify things by their similarities does not mean they are related. To prove something is related, it must be an exact match. And no, their diet does not prove they’re related.
3. Variations of animals after their kinds: And animals reproduce after their parents. Which means, even if they have lost the ability to interbreed, you can still examine their features to say either they are the same animal or they are not. For example, a turkey, chicken, pheasant, and peakhawk are all different variations of the same kind of animal. Especially when compared to any variation of the pigeon kind.
4. Bonus: Here’s an experiment to show how nature works: if I have a whole chocolate chip cookie, and break it apart and give one part to each person, all the parts would look different. And as those people would break it apart and give those parts to other people, those parts would also look different, but you can still observe, test, and verify that all of those parts belong to the chocolate chip cookie. Compared to an Oreo cookie or a sugar cookie. Some parts might have a large chunk of chocolate chip in them, others might not, but you can still tell which original cookie each chunk belongs to. And by having all the parts, you can see every detail in which that cookie originally had. Just like a sudoku puzzle, we are able to make amazing predictions which result in being correct, due to the precision of using this method.

The 7 examples discussed were what are called "microevolution." Simply a change in frequencies of alleles (existing genetic traits.) I counter that those who are predisposed to believe in evolution tend to want to claim everything is proof of evolution. If you claim I have bias, then they also have bias the other way. It is best to be objective.

The claim is made that if microevolution is true, then this will eventually lead to macroevolution. Breeding experiments have been carried out for decades, over hundreds and even thousands of generations on fruit flies, micro-organisms and plants. It has been found that there is a limit to how much they can change. It is always within what was already genetically present in the organism. They never become something other than fruit flies or Staphylococcus or whatever they started out with. The expression by the Creator that creatures reproduce "according to their kinds" (roughly equivalent to classification "Family" appears proven to be true.

My contention is that though proponents like to call it microevolution it isn't actually evolution, because no innovations have occurred, merely breeding. In the illustration I gave before where someone kills everyone without red hair, in a couple generations should a researcher come through and say, "Wow, what an example of amazingly rapid evolution! Practically the whole population has red hair now." Yeah sure, there has been a genetic shift in allele frequencies, but they haven't ACTUALLY changed significantly. It is just a cosmetic difference that was already present.

In my view, how wonderful that our Creator kindly crammed a bunch of potential genetic diversity in every Kind of organism. Thus we can have many types of dogs, of cats, horses, people, roses, bananas, corn, etc. This provides enjoyable variety in taste, color, size, resiliency, etc. Most changes are just cosmetic. Having different races of human is excellent, but it is mostly all just surface features that vary. Their internal organs and cells (the important stuff) pretty much works the same way.

For evolution to be true, it would have to produce NEW strings of genetic code. There are countless fantastic innovations. The eye, ear, lungs, blood, clotting ability, stages of reproduction, stages of digestion, peristalsis, numerous sphincters, so many wondrous functions we take for granted until they don't work (often because a mutation bad enough to be called a genetic disease threw a spanner in the works.)

So no, I don't consider so-called microevolution to ACTUALLY be evolution. Not just because of my potential bias, but because it isn't enough to produce new abilities, which is what evolution is supposed to be able to do eventually. I know the difference between a merry-go-round and a train. Also, a paint job doesn't make an existing house a new one. It just a "bait and switch" con. Say some truth to get someone agreeing with you and then blur the lines to an unwarranted conclusion.

Microevolution does not lead to macroevolution and thus really isn't proof of evolution at all.

Hank Green, I myself have noticed an example of extreme evolution right here in Charlotte, NC. Twenty-five years ago, I used to work in downtown Charlotte often, and there were roadkill squirrels absolutely everywhere. About two and a half decades later, this is not that case. The main thing that I've observed that is likely responsible for this change is their fleeing behavior. When I started to observe them, they would dart across the road to get away from one vehicle, then instantly double back on themselves and cross the road again. This was likely a way to confuse and outrun predators, but it does not work well with vehicles. Twenty-five years later, I've noticed both that they dart across the street a single time and keep going, and also that there is vastly less roadkill than before.

As I suspected, none of these are actually examples of evolution. None of them actually showed NEW capabilities coming as a result of accidental genetic change. They were all simply attributes which the creatures already had and were within their existing range of genetic diversity. There can be a bit of natural selection of EXISTING traits, but it's all around a mean or average. Take the cliff swallows, for example. Some already HAD short wings. Nothing NEW came into being. If the conditions changed they would revert back. They are just oscillating around a mean. They are not actually GOING anywhere or truly changing or improving.


In no case did they become another new type of creature. Cliff swallows were still cliff swallows, etc. Elephants were still elephants.
It is a wonderful design to allow variety within a family of creatures. This keeps them from all being wiped out by a particular adversity. Variations in size, color and so forth are pleasant to enjoy and also allow resilience.


It has been discovered (and even discussed on Sci-Show) that there is such a thing as Epigenetics. Creatures have a great deal of extra genetic coding ALREADY existing within there genome and ready to respond to environmental stimuli. Thus, they do not need a NEW mutation giving them some new ability (as if random single point mutations could actually do that.) Fully functioning long strings of code already exist to help adapt within a predetermined range. I watched a different video showing that even consuming plastic was within the EXISTING capabilities of certain bacteria since it wasn't that different from something they already were capable of consuming. (They put some micro-organism which they knew had never interacted with plastics and a sub-set were able to consume it.)


I consider the concept that if the genetics shifts a little at all, even within existing traits, that this means evolution has occurred. That is a very wussy, grasp at straws version of evolution. If all variety in life came about by evolution, then evolution has to actually introduce new traits by means of new genetic coding. Not simple going round and round in a circle of pre-existing genetics. You've got to code something NEW or you aren't actually something new. Slightly shorter wings is simple existing genes being expressed a little less. No new coding required. A mutation which keeps an elephant from being able to grow tusks is a LOSS of information, not anything new.


Let me illustrate what I mean. If some psychopath killed everyone in a community who didn't have red hair and in future generations red hair was much more common, was that evolution? That is pretty much what most of the 7 examples presenting in the video amounted to. Some outside force killing those that didn't have a certain existing trait. My whole point is genetic information was LOST, not gained. That's not really an example of evolution, just variety within a group and maybe de-evolution if anything, since variety was lost.

Obviously, this is just one person's observation and my subjective interpretation of it, but when I started driving here in the UK in the 1970s it was really common to hit a rabbit on the road. They'd just run out in front of you, particularly at night. Folklore stated that they were attracted by the headlights. Now, forty five years later, this very rarely happens; you often see rabbits on the verge, but they almost never run out any more. It has occurred to me that rabbits with a behavioural tendency to run out into traffic may have gradually died out (by being hit by cars), leaving survivors that don't have this tendency. Of course, this would require behaviours as well as physical attributes to be passed on genetically, but it's just a thought.

As bad as it might be for marine life, the tragic truth is that the best thing we can hope to have happen to those plastics is just that, to be taken up by marine life and sink to the bottom. Much as that's awful, the last thing we want is for all that plastic to be converted through photodegradation into CO2 sources, it's better for it to be sequestered as deep as it possibly can be.

IDEALLY, we'd use plastic as a pump slurry material for oil driling, a sludge of normally sand and detergents and water meant to loosen crude from underground so it can be pumped back out(as well as to take up the space it occupied. Think of blowing into a glass to push the liquid up). Shredded down into tiny enough pellets, it would effectively work to replace the sand used. That way we could sequester that plastic rather than just letting it sit in landfills or break down in the sun, which would at the very least slow down the CO2 problem, though of course, cutting drilling entirely would work a lot better, but for our lifestyles to work right now in the modern age, that's just not gonna be possible for a good long while.

I travel a lot by road here in Australia. Kangaroos seem to be particularly prone to road traffic. They are active generally from dusk to dawn and tend not to move away from approaching cars or trucks - they are likely to stare stupidly into the headlights until it's too late. I've often wondered if there is a measurable change in behaviour for kangaroo populations now compared to, say, the 1950's when road traffic started to really ramp up. With a kangaroo "generation" being around 6-8 years, that's about 10 generations since the 50's. You would think that evolution would favour more road wary individuals. My experience suggests not - there are still a LOT of kangaroos being naturally de-selected... But I'd be interested to learn if anyone has formally studied this.

Since evolution is a response to the environment, it doesn't seem unusual at all for fast evolution to respond to fast environmental change. For example, once C-Sections in humans became a common hospital practice, they suddenly became a necessary hospital practice. Limitations in humans that prevent natural birth are now passed on to children, and daughters of women who had C-Sections will likely need them as well since those genetic factors may be present in them. The invention and perfection of the C-Section was a relatively quick environmental change that allowed for the variety of humankind to expand, and given that a large baby head/brain is one of those varieties and that it's also a benefit for babies to be born with one, it's not a surprise that this variety of human is slowly becoming more prevalent and may eventually be the norm.

"Rapidly adapt" is not the same as "rapidly evolve". Frogs at Mt. St. Helens rapidly adapted to the high heat environment by externalizing their reproductive organs and internalizing their offspring and giving birth to fully formed frogs, and then 20 years later reverted back. Adaptation is not evolution.

Not only this, we know what causes it. It is a gene marker turning on or off. It is not a change to the structure of the creature's DNA.

"Can't mate" and "don't want to mate" are two different things. Those mosquitos can mate with other types. Their DNA is, in fact, compatible. They just prefer not to. It's not even remotely the same thing. It is not speciation; it is racial preference. (Which is a survival mechanism, being fear of difference.)
